author: craigmcc
msg: If the request came in on an SSL connection, and if the client presented a
certificate chain to authenticate itself, the array of certificates is
exposed as a request attribute under key
"javax.servlet.request.X509Certificate", as required by Section 4.7 of the
Servlet 2.3 Specification (Public Draft 1).
Also cleaned up a couple of bugs in the way that Valve pipelines were
constructed and reported.

author: craigmcc
msg: Make the underlying socket visible on a request, so that an SSL
authentication module (for running Standalone) can extract the current
SSLSession and therefore the peer certificate chain.

author: craigmcc
msg: Reflect the changes just checked in for the server socket factory.
NOTE:  If you ask createConnection() for a secure connection, it will set up
an SSLServerSocketFactory for you, with default values.  To modify the defaults
you will need to acquire a reference to this object, and modify its properties,
before you start the connector.  Code to do this might look like this:
Connector connector = embedded.createConnector(null, 443, true);
SSLServerSocketFactory factory =
(SSLServerSocketFactory) connector.getFactory();
factory.setClientAuth(true);

author: craigmcc
msg: Make configuration of the server socket factory consistent with all the
other component configuration that is done in server.xml, by defining a
new "Server/Connector/Factory" parsing rule.  The default server socket
factory returns unadorned java.net.ServerSocket sockets, while the SSL
server socket factory can be configured via XML attributes in the usual
way.

author: craigmcc
msg: Do not include the JSSE jar files in $CATALINA_HOME/server -- due to the
way that class loading is implemented in Catalina, JSSE *must* be
installed as a system extension (in $JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/ext), as described
in the JSSE documentation.
You can now enable simultaneous non-SSL and SSL connectors with Tomcat 4.0
stand-alone, once you follow the directions in the "conf/server.xml" file
and uncomment the entry that enables this connector.  The default SSL port
is 8443 -- you won't be able to run on port 443 on Unix systems unless you
are running as root, which is not a good idea.
Next step is to add initial logic that deals with client authentication
and certificates.
